experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. Honestly, I'm just feeling a bit overwhelmed trying to figure everything out before I graduate.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! Totally get that feeling—it’s normal to feel overwhelmed. Since you’re outgoing and open, use that to your advantage: reach out to professors or alumni for mentorship—they can help with grad school advice and career direction. For finances, check if your university offers free financial planning workshops. And for public speaking, try practicing in smaller clubs first to build confidence. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I've been meaning to ask professors about mentorship, but I keep worrying I'll pick the wrong person and waste their time. And those financial workshops... I always mean to go, but then I get stressed just thinking about my student loan numbers.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory! It's totally okay to feel that way—professors expect students to ask for guidance, so don't stress about "wasting their time." Start with one you admire; they'll appreciate your initiative. For loans, break it down: attend just one workshop or meet a financial aid advisor. Small steps build confidence, and you're capable of handling this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I guess I could try emailing Professor Davies first - her research aligns pretty closely with what I want to do for grad school. It's just hard not to feel like I'm bothering people when they're so busy.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great first step! Professor Davies will likely appreciate your initiative—it shows genuine interest in her work. Remember, professors expect and want to mentor students like you. Keep the email concise and specific about your goals. You're not bothering her; you're building a valuable connection. Go for it!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, you're right - I'll draft something tonight while I'm feeling brave. It's just hard to shake that feeling that I'm intruding on her time.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's the anxiety talking, not reality. Professors choose this career partly to mentor students like you. Drafting that email while feeling brave is perfect—trust that impulse. You're taking control of your future, not intruding. Hit send before you overthink it!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I always overthink these things until the moment passes. Maybe I'll just write "interested in your research" and hit send before my brain comes up with twenty reasons not to.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Exactly! That's the perfect approach—short, genuine, and action-oriented. You're being proactive about your goals, which is exactly what mentors admire. Sending it quickly stops the overthinking cycle. You've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I just need to treat it like ripping off a bandage - the longer I wait, the more it's gonna hurt. I'll keep it simple and send it before I start questioning whether my email signature looks professional enough.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's the spirit! Overthinking is the real enemy here. A simple, polite email is all you need—professors care more about your interest than perfect formatting. Sending it quickly is smart. Proud of you for pushing through the nerves!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I needed to hear that. It's funny how I can debug code for hours but spend days stressing over three sentences to a professor.

personality_evolution_timeline.conversation_summary: Gregory discussed his anxiety about finding a mentor and financial planning, specifically his fear of bothering Professor Davies. Through coaching, he developed a concrete plan to send a brief email about her research, recognizing his tendency to overthink simple communications.

fears.Choosing the right career path: fear of picking the wrong professor for mentorship and wasting their time
fears.Social anxiety in large lecture halls: fear of bothering Professor Davies when she's busy with her own work
fears.Academic failure and poor grades: fear that email signature won't look professional enough to a professor

challenges.Finding a mentor: specifically emailing Professor Davies about her research and grad school guidance
challenges.Financial planning: attending one financial workshop or meeting with a financial aid advisor about loan numbers

behaviors.Participates in study groups: debugging code for hours without stress compared to writing emails
behaviors.Volunteers for campus events: drafting an email to a professor while feeling brave to build connections

triggers.Networking events: writing a three-sentence email to Professor Davies about research interests
triggers.Presentations: overthinking email content and signature professionalism before sending

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thanks for meeting with me. I've been really struggling with the social aspects of college, especially the group projects in my computer science courses.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 9/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 8/10 (Very organized)
- Neuroticism: 4/10 (Moderately sensitive)
- Openness: 1/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 9/10 (Severe)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Office hours, Group projects, Job interviews, Presentations
- Social comfort: 2/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Living away from family for the first time, Time management with coursework
- Goals: Develop leadership skills, Build a strong professional network
- Challenges: Career exploration, Dealing with academic pressure, Navigating campus politics, Building time management
- Behaviors: Joins student clubs and organizations, Procrastinates on assignments, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Stays up late studying

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey, I totally get it—group projects can be tough when you're feeling anxious. I found that starting with small steps helps, like messaging one teammate first to break the ice. Also, setting clear roles early on reduces stress. You're not alone in this; many of us feel the same way. Want to try practicing a conversation opener together?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I can message one person first, but my hands get shaky just thinking about it. Setting roles sounds helpful—at least then I'd know exactly what's expected of me.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That’s a great start—knowing your role can ease so much pressure. For the nerves, try typing your message first and taking a deep breath before hitting send. You’ve got this, and each small step builds confidence. Want to draft that message together now?

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Okay, I'll try typing it out first. Can we make it really simple? Like just "Hi, I'm Jamie - what part of the project should I focus on?"

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect! That's clear, polite, and opens the door for them to take the lead. It’s a great message. Remember to breathe before you send it—you're being proactive, and that's huge. I'm proud of you for taking this step. You can do this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, that helps. I'll practice breathing first. It's just hard when my mind goes blank trying to think of what to say.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's totally normal—your mind goes blank under pressure. Try keeping a few simple, go-to phrases handy for moments like that. "What's our next step?" or "How can I help?" work in almost any situation. You're building a skill, and it gets easier with practice. You're already doing great by facing this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: That's actually really practical advice. I'm going to write those phrases down in my notebook so I don't blank out next time.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a smart move! Having a "cheat sheet" of go-to phrases takes the pressure off in social situations. It's a simple but effective strategy that builds confidence over time. Keep practicing—you're developing a valuable professional skill!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I'll add those phrases right now. It's just... sometimes I worry that even with preparation, I'll still freeze up when someone actually responds to me.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a valid fear, and it happens to a lot of us. When someone responds, you don't need a perfect reply—just focus on listening. A simple "That's helpful, thanks" or "Could you tell me more?" keeps the conversation going smoothly. You're preparing well, which already puts you ahead. You've got this.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I'll try to remember that. It's just hard to think straight when my heart starts racing during conversations.

personality_evolution_timeline.conversation_summary: Jamie discussed anxiety around initiating group project communication and received coaching on practical strategies, including drafting messages, using go-to phrases, and breathing techniques, showing willingness to implement these tools despite persistent fears of freezing during conversations.

fears.Finding a job after graduation: Freezing up during a job interview when asked a question
fears.Living away from family for the first ti: Feeling isolated and unsupported during stressful group projects
fears.Time management with coursework: Procrastinating on group project tasks due to social anxiety

challenges.Career exploration: Developing professional communication skills needed for job interviews
challenges.Dealing with academic pressure: Managing anxiety during mandatory group projects in computer science
challenges.Navigating campus politics: Initiating contact and establishing roles with unfamiliar teammates
challenges.Building time management: Allocating time to draft and mentally prepare for social messages

behaviors.Procrastinates on assignments: Delaying the initial message to a group project teammate
behaviors.Calls family frequently: Seeking reassurance before engaging in stressful social interactions
behaviors.Stays up late studying: Spending excessive time worrying about and preparing for simple social exchanges

triggers.Group projects: The moment of sending the first message to a computer science project teammate
triggers.Job interviews: The moment someone responds to a question and a reply is expected
triggers.Presentations: The anticipation of having to speak in a group setting where roles are undefined
